title: Trump admin. 'acting with urgency' with xLight stake: Pat Gelsinger
summary: The Trump administration will be taking an equity stake in semiconductor manufacturer startup xLight with a $150 million investment. xLight executive chair Pat Gelsinger sits down with Yahoo Finance executive editor Brian Sozzi to discuss xLight's chip technology, domestic chip production, the US Department of Commerce's investment, and his perspective on the AI ecosystem as OpenAI (OPAI.PVT) issues a "code red" over tightening competition and Alphabet's (GOOG, GOOGL) new spot as a top AI contender. Gelsinger is also the general partner of Playground Global and was the CEO of Intel (INTC) from 2021 until December 2024. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.

title: FDA scrutiny of WHOOP signals challenges for niche wearable device makers
summary: Niche fitness-tracking firms such as WHOOP are coming under increased regulatory scrutiny as technological advances blur the lines between wearable and medical devices, exposing them to higher compliance costs ​and hampering their competitive advantage.  Although the U.S. Food and Drug Administration regulates certain health-focused tools in wearable devices such as smartwatches, many ‌companies have until now used a "regulatory gray zone" to bundle apps such as blood pressure monitors under advanced wellness features, without formal approvals.  However, the regulator has started to crack the ‌whip by making it clear that features such as blood pressure monitoring may be used by consumers to manage underlying health conditions and therefore would need its approval.

raw.headline: FDA scrutiny of WHOOP signals challenges for niche wearable device makers
raw.summary: Niche fitness-tracking firms such as WHOOP are coming under increased regulatory scrutiny as technological advances blur the lines between wearable and medical devices, exposing them to higher compliance costs ​and hampering their competitive advantage.  Although the U.S. Food and Drug Administration regulates certain health-focused tools in wearable devices such as smartwatches, many ‌companies have until now used a "regulatory gray zone" to bundle apps such as blood pressure monitors under advanced wellness features, without formal approvals.  However, the regulator has started to crack the ‌whip by making it clear that features such as blood pressure monitoring may be used by consumers to manage underlying health conditions and therefore would need its approval.

title: IDC sees global smartphone shipments dipping in 2026 as memory costs bite
summary: Global smartphone shipments are expected to decline by 0.9% in 2026 as rising memory chip ​prices are pushing average selling prices to record highs, according to research ‌firm IDC.  The drop follows a stronger 2025, when shipments are forecast to grow 1.5% to 1.‌25 billion units, driven by Apple's strong performance and a rebound in China.  Apple is on track for a record year in 2025, with shipments projected to rise 6.1% to 247 million units, helped by surging demand for its iPhone 17 ⁠series.

raw.headline: IDC sees global smartphone shipments dipping in 2026 as memory costs bite
raw.summary: Global smartphone shipments are expected to decline by 0.9% in 2026 as rising memory chip ​prices are pushing average selling prices to record highs, according to research ‌firm IDC.  The drop follows a stronger 2025, when shipments are forecast to grow 1.5% to 1.‌25 billion units, driven by Apple's strong performance and a rebound in China.  Apple is on track for a record year in 2025, with shipments projected to rise 6.1% to 247 million units, helped by surging demand for its iPhone 17 ⁠series.
